title: Charge conservation - two spheres with 7e and -2e

content.question: In an experiment, two microscopic conducting spheres are made from the same solid material and have the same diameter. One sphere has a net charge of <math alttext="positive 7 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math> and the other has a net charge of <math alttext="negative 2 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math>. The spheres are briefly brought into contact and are then separated. After the experiment, which of the following correctly describes the most likely charges of the spheres and provides valid evidence or reasoning to support the claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="positive 2.5 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math> on each sphere. Electrons move from the negative sphere to the positive sphere so that the total net charge is divided evenly between the two spheres.

<math alttext="positive 2.5 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math> on each sphere. Protons move from the positive sphere to the negative sphere so that the <math alttext="positive 5 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math> total net charge is divided evenly between the two spheres.

<math alttext="positive 2 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math> on one sphere and <math alttext="positive 3 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math> on the other sphere. Electrons move from the negative sphere to the positive sphere so that the <math alttext="positive 5 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math> total net charge is divided as evenly as possible between the two spheres.

<math alttext="positive 2 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math> on one sphere and <math alttext="positive 3 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math> on the other sphere. Protons move from the positive sphere to the negative sphere so that the <math alttext="positive 5 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math> total net charge is divided as evenly as possible between the two spheres.

content.answer: <math alttext="positive 2 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math> on one sphere and <math alttext="positive 3 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math> on the other sphere. Electrons move from the negative sphere to the positive sphere so that the <math alttext="positive 5 e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>e</mi></mpadded></math> total net charge is divided as evenly as possible between the two spheres.
